docs.lead_paragraph: It seems hard to imagine anything more heartbreaking than giving birth to a severely handicapped child, unless it is not having a say in how it should, or shouldn't, be treated. Last week, a Federal judge eased the dilemma, if not the pain, by striking down the Reagan Administration's recent effort to regulate the issue -the ''Baby Doe'' rule - as a ''hasty, ill-considered'' intrusion into ''one of the most difficult and sensitive medical and ethical problems.''

byline.original: By Margot Slade and Wayne Biddle

docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal district judge today struck down a new rule that required 6,400 hospitals around the country to provide food and medical care to infants born with severe mental or physical defects. Judge Gerhard A. Gesell said that the rule, issued by the Reagan Administration March 7, was ''arbitrary and capricious.'' Further, he said, it was adopted in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act, which requires Government agencies to give the public an opportunity to comment on most rules. Therefore, he said the rule was invalid and ''has no further force or effect.'' The Administration announced it would appeal Judge Gesell's ruling.

headline.main: JUDGE STRIKES RULE REQUIRING CARE FOR INFANTS WITH DEFECTS
